newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria-Russia bank to raise capital to 5 bln lvs.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria-Russia bank to raise capital to 5 bln lvs.

text.p: The private Bulgarian-Russian Investment Bank (BRIB) plans to raise its capital four-fold to five billion levs by the end of 1998 to meet new central bank minimum capital requirements, the bank's chief executive director said.
"The bank's board will propose at the shareholders' meeting on October 5 to raise the capital to five billion levs from 1.25 billion levs through a new share issue," Svetoslav Bozhilov told Reuters.

Bozhilov said "We hope to raise our capital to 2.5-2.7 billion levs by the end of March next year because there is an interest from potential subscribers for some 1.5 billion levs worth of shares from the new issue."

The central bank raised minimum capital requirements for commercial banks on August 15 to 1.4 billion levs and 2.2 billion levs for a domestic and a full banking licence, respectively. That compared with previous requirements of 800 million levs and 1.2 billion levs, respectively.
The new requirements are to be met by licensed banks by March 31, 1997. BRIB got a full banking licence in January 1995.
Par value of the new shares will remain unchanged at 10,000 levs, Bozhilov said. The stocks will be offered to current shareholders and, after negotiations, to other investors.
The bank's rise in capital will also help it avoid subsequent rises in the short term, which could be called for if the lev falls further, Bozhilov said.
He said the bank plans to have the capital of five billion levs fully paid-in by the end of 1998. -- Roumiana Tikholova, Sofia Newsroom, 359-2-84561
